In this paper it's just used for outlier detection, but you could imagine doing unsupervised clustering with such a distance metric.
Then the forest picks up on the correlations and de-weights irrelevant features that don't capture relationships in the real data.
Now, train a forest to label real data as "real" and fake data with the same marginal distributions, but no correlations, as "synthetic".
So if 90% of your features are useless for classification, even similar things can end up being far away in Manhattan distance or similar.
Distance and volume measures in high dimensions have weird behavior and you want to zero in on the features that really matter.
It looks like the idea is to *learn* a distance measure for clustering, rather than just using Euclidean distance or some default measure.
So I checked it out and it's pretty clever -- though it wasn't at all clear to me at first why one would use random… https://t.co/9dByhvt7vM

Maybe then I will give a more pictorial explanation -- I'm a visual thinker and really need to draw this stuff to get my points across
There are ways to address this and they're what I've been banging my head against for a while now. More later if one of them works.
Those who know linear algebra will see that with more dimensions than samples, the (sample) covariance matrix won't be invertible. Awkward.
For direct relationships you control pairs of variables vs. all other variables in your set -- equivalent to inverting the covariance matrix
Overall relationships between variables can be summarized by a covariance matrix, which you can build even with more dimensions than samples
I can honestly say I've never had that problem before. ;) Very keen to see what you've got for us tomorrow! https://t.co/M4pb5XtkvJ
...as opposed to straight-up regressions, which don't care whether correlations are direct (A -> B) or in a chain (A -> B -> ... -> Z)
In this case "graphical model" is an umbrella term here for things that capture direct relationships between variables...
Even simple graphical models are pretty challenging -- you need a LOT of data, usually much more than you have in biology applications.
In non-political news, today I'll keep trying to build a #graphicalmodel of long-term effects of #nutrition and #microbiome on mouse health.
